Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged
This needs proper error handling in place of the `assert()` and needs to address the NULL dereference.

As discussed in the commit below the use case we are trying to achieve, we had an OEM-IBM method written but we received a comment about not using #if_def in the generic files - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63155/7/src/pdr.c#8
So we moved the method to the generic src/pdr.c file and made the magic number used as a constant in a generic platform file with OEM_range- https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63612/3/include/libpldm/platform.h
We took an example from here - https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/entity.h#L140
I can rename the constant with the OEM symbol in it.

Could you please help us with how to go about it for the use case specified and the constraints we have?
I have made changes according to the comment received here - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/63155/7/src/oem/ibm/pdr.c#31
Why is this something we want to do?
We need this to identify the records within a particular range, as BMC and remote endpoints have their own ranges defined for the PDR record handles they own.
Do we need to document that the point is opaque here?
Ack
The symbol name contains no indication that it's an OEM symbol. And if it is an OEM symbol it should mention *which* OEM, and be exposed in an OEM header file (not the generic platform header file).
Ack
Please do not use `assert()` for handling bad parameters values. You must signal a failure to the caller through a return value.
Ack
You're already dereferencing `curr` before testing whether it is NULL, which leads to UB.
Done
This patch affects the PDR subsystem, so please prefix the subject with `pdr: `.
Done

Generally if you're starting a sentence with "This commit ..." it indicates that you're explaining *what*, not *why*. We need the *why* in the commit message. Why would someone want to find the last record?
Done
Range of what?
Done

Hi Pavithra, there's a bit of a problem regarding inclusive vs exclusive ranges. That's the primary concern.

I've also suggested an approach to tidying up the search loop that eliminates many of the variables we have currently.

There should also be tests provided for this new functionality.
Done
`first` itself isn't a range, it's the first record handle value in the range. The documentation should state that it's value is a handle value.
Done

As above, `last` itself isn't a range, just an element. The documentation should state that it's value is a handle value.

That said, you need to indicate whether the range is open or closed at each end. Intuitively this range should be closed at both ends.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_(mathematics)#Terminology

However, there are several ways to represent the range, the way we have it here, and `[start, length]`. I'm honestly not sure which we should choose, but I went with `[first, last]`. What do you think?
[first, last] fits better I feel Andrew.

Is this an IBM-specific value? If so it should not be defined in this file (`include/libpldm/platform.h`). At worst it should be defined in an OEM include. Ideally we'd not define it in libpldm at all.
Ack

Please make sure declarations occur before code. I realise that's no longer required, but it does retain alignment with Linux's C style requirements (which are the style requirements for C in OpenBMC).
since we are dereferencing the repo, the 'repo == NULL' check should happen first right?.
Done
These inequalities make the provided range exclusive, not inclusive. That's not right as it makes impossible to include handle values at extremes.
Ack
Done
Just one comment on the ABI annotation at the moment.
This must be `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`. I acknowledge that how to choose the annotation wasn't yet documented, so I've set about fixing that in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/64074
Done
